p.text: A person who is or was a member of the clergy of any church or religious denomination is entitled to refuse to divulge that a religious confession was made, or the contents of a religious confession made, to the person when a member of the clergy.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the communication involved in the religious confession was made for a criminal purpose.
This section applies even if an Act provides:
that the rules of evidence do not apply or that a person or body is not bound by the rules of evidence, or
that a person is not excused from answering any question or producing any document or other thing on the ground of privilege or any other ground.
In this section:
means a confession made by a person to a member of the clergy in the member's professional capacity according to the ritual of the church or religious denomination concerned.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,135] s 128 Privilege in respect of self-incrimination in other proceedings

leg:heading.title: Privilege in respect of self-incrimination in other proceedings

p.text: This section applies if a witness objects to giving particular evidence, or evidence on a particular matter, on the ground that the evidence may tend to prove that the witness:
has committed an offence against or arising under an Australian law or a law of a foreign country, or
is liable to a civil penalty.
The court must determine whether or not there are reasonable grounds for the objection.
Subject to subsection (4), if the court determines that there are reasonable grounds for the objection, the court is not to require the witness to give the evidence, and is to inform the witness:
that the witness need not give the evidence unless required by the court to do so under subsection (4) , and
that the court will give a certificate under this section if:
the witness willingly gives the evidence without being required to do so under subsection (4) , or
the witness gives the evidence after being required to do so under subsection (4) , and
of the effect of such a certificate.
[subs (3) am Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[1], [2], effective 14 January 2011]
The court may require the witness to give the evidence if the court is satisfied that:
the evidence does not tend to prove that the witness has committed an offence against or arising under, or is liable to a civil penalty under, a law of a foreign country, and
the interests of justice require that the witness give the evidence.

If the witness either willingly gives the evidence without being required to do so under subsection (4) , or gives it after being required to do so under that subsection, the court must cause the witness to be given a certificate under this section in respect of the evidence.
The court is also to cause a witness to be given a certificate under this section if:
the objection has been overruled, and
after the evidence has been given, the court finds that there were reasonable grounds for the objection.
In any proceeding in a NSW court or before any person or body authorised by a law of this State, or by consent of parties, to hear, receive and examine evidence:
evidence given by a person in respect of which a certificate under this section has been given, and
evidence of any information, document or thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person having given evidence,
cannot be used against the person. However, this does not apply to a criminal proceeding in respect of the falsity of the evidence.
This subsection differs from section 128(7) of the Commonwealth Act. The Commonwealth provision refers to an “Australian Court” instead of a “NSW court”.
Subsection (7) has effect despite any challenge, review, quashing or calling into question on any ground of the decision to give, or the validity of, the certificate concerned.

If a defendant in a criminal proceeding for an offence is given a certificate under this section, subsection (7) does not apply in a proceeding that is a retrial of the defendant for the same offence or a trial of the defendant for an offence arising out of the same facts that gave rise to that offence.
In a criminal proceeding, this section does not apply in relation to the giving of evidence by a defendant, being evidence that the defendant:
did an act the doing of which is a fact in issue, or
had a state of mind the existence of which is a fact in issue.
A reference in this section to doing an act includes a reference to failing to act.

If a person has been given a certificate under a prescribed State or Territory provision in respect of evidence given by a person in a proceeding in a State or Territory court, the certificate has the same effect, in a proceeding to which this subsection applies, as if it had been given under this section.
[subs (12) insrt Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[3], effective 14 January 2011]

For the purposes of subsection (12) , a prescribed State or Territory provision is a provision of a law of a State or Territory declared by the regulations to be a prescribed State or Territory provision for the purposes of that subsection.
[subs (13) insrt Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[3], effective 14 January 2011]

Subsection (12) applies to a proceeding in relation to which this Act applies because of section 4, other than a proceeding for an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or for the recovery of a civil penalty under a law of the Commonwealth.
[subs (14) insrt Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[3], effective 14 January 2011]
Bodies corporate cannot claim this privilege. See section 187 .
Clause 3 of Part 2 of the Dictionary sets out what is a civil penalty.

Section 128(12)–(14) of the Commonwealth Act give effect to certificates in relation to self-incriminating evidence under the NSW Act in proceedings in federal and ACT courts and in prosecutions for Commonwealth and ACT offences.
Subsections (8) and (9) were inserted as a response to the decision of the High Court of Australia in Cornwell v The Queen [2007] HCA 12 (22 March 2007).
[s 128 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[61], effective 1 January 2009 ; am Act No 69 of 2010 Sch 1[4], effective 14 January 2011]
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 852–861, 862
ALRC 38 paras 214–217
Legislation cited in [51,135.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 3.
As defined in cl 3 of Part 2 of the Dictionary, the term “civil penalty” includes a penalties arising under both Australian and foreign law.

At common law a witness cannot be compelled to provide an answer to a question where the answer might, as a matter of reasonable possibility, tend to expose the witness to criminal prosecution: Ex parte P ; Re Hamilton; Ex parte P (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 397 at 399 ; R v Boyes (1861) 1 B & S 311; 121 ER 730; Ex parte Reynolds (1882) 20 Ch D 294 ; Lamb v Munster (1882) 10 QBD 110 . See generally [s 87.15] – [s 87.35] .

Proceedings involve a civil penalty if they expose the witness to a risk of any penalty arising under either Australian or foreign law. Examples of proceedings that fall within the description of a civil penalty include fines under the Trade Practices Act (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010): Pyneboard Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 152 CLR 328; 45 ALR 609 ; proceedings for a breach of police regulations: Police Service Board v Morris (1985) 156 CLR 397; 58 ALR 1 ; Attorney-General of NSW v Borland [2007] NSWCA 201; BC200706642 (Coroner has discretion to sustain or overrule an objection by a witness to giving evidence which might expose him to a civil penalty — in this case, disciplinary action by the Commissioner of Police — but in exercising that discretion the fact that a certificate under s 33AA of the Coroner’s Act 1980 would not protect the witness against the risk of a civil penalty was “a most material consideration”).
Legislation cited in [51,135.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128.

There was no common law power to override the privilege against incrimination. The present section permits a court to require answers to questions where the witness could otherwise have claimed the the privilege against self incrimination. The power is subject to two conditions. First, the incrimination risk must relate only to Australian law. Second the court must be satisfied it is in the interests of justice to require an answer to the question: Versace v Monte [2001] FCA 1572; BC200107025 . See Woods v Smith [1976] WAR 13 ; Attorney-General (WA) v Cockram (1990) 2 WAR 477 .

The issue of a certificate under s 128 precludes the evidence being used against the person in any proceedings in any NSW court or adjudicative authority — except proceedings relating to the falsity of the evidence. (There is no legislative basis on which a NSW provision could, of its own force, affect the admissibility of such evidence in another jurisdiction: Sharp v Australian Builders Labourers' Federated Union of Workers [1989] WAR 138 .)

The purpose of the section is to permit, indeed compel, the giving of material evidence material whilst simultaneously attempting to preserve the practical benefit of the privilege in relation to any subsequent criminal or civil penalty proceedings against the witness: Ollis v Melissari [2005] NSWSC 1016; BC200507835 .

The section clearly applies whenever a witness objects to giving particular evidence in cross-examination, however there are presently differing views as to whether it can apply to evidence-in-chief (or, for that matter, to evidence in re-examination). The decision of the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in Ferrall v Blyton (2000) 27 Fam LR 178; (2000) FLC 93-054; [2000] FamCA 1442 , as well as the decisions in Chao v Chao [2008] NSWSC 584; BC200804324 and Sheikholeslami v Tolcher (2009) 75 NSWLR 418; [2009] NSWSC 920; BC200908187 generally support the view that the section applies to evidence in chief. Similarly, the decision in Ollis v Melissari [2005] NSWSC 1016; BC200507835 ; supports the view that the section applies to evidence given in re-examination.

A different view was expressed in Meiko Australia Pacific Pty Ltd v Hinchliffe [2009] NSWSC 354; BC200903584 . The issue was referred to, although not authoritatively determined, by the High Court in Cornwell v R (2007) 231 CLR 260; 234 ALR 51; [2007] HCA 12; BC200701731 at [111] where the reasoning which was adopted was suggestive of a view that s 128 does not apply to evidence-in-chief. In a subsequent decision of Reliance Financial Services NSW Pty Ltd v Sobbi [2009] NSWSC 1375; BC200911513 the court concluded (in the context of considering whether the section applied to evidence given in re-examination) that the reasoning adopted in Ferrall was not correct and the reasoning in Cornwell should be preferred.

The Court of Appeal in Song v Ying [2010] NSWCA 237; BC201006767 concluded that if a witness gives evidence in chief because he or she is actually compelled to do so (by subpoena and threat of imprisonment), or because of the availability of such compulsion if he or she does not do so, there is no reason why that witness may not object to giving evidence in chief on the ground that the evidence may tend to incriminate. The conclusion was reached that in those circumstances, if the requirements of s 128 were otherwise satisfied, there would be no reason why a certificate could not be issued and that the decision of the High Court in Cornwell should not be regarded as authority for restricting the application of s 128 to cross examination. There remain, however, differing views as to the issue and that is likely to remain the position until such time as it is authoritatively considered by the High Court at some point in the future.

In determining whether a witness should be required to answer a question in relation to which they have claimed privilege, "the interests of justice" may extend to matters affecting the witness’ credit: Cureton v Blackshaw Services Pty Ltd [2002] NSWCA 187; BC200203514 ; R v Collisson (2003) 139 A Crim R 389; [2003] NSWCCA 212; BC200304289 ; Kang-Kem v Paine [2003] NSWSC 916; BC200306039 ; Ollis v Melissari [2005] NSWSC 1016; BC200507835 (objection taken in the course of re-examination).
Legislation cited in [51,135.26] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128, s 187.

The provisions of s 128 do not extend to the incrimination of a corporation, however close the association might be between the corporation and the person who is giving evidence. The common law privilege in respect of a corporation was abolished by the High Court in Environmental Protection Authority v Caltex Refining Co Ltd (1993) 178 CLR 477; 118 ALR 392; 68 ALJR 127; BC9303552 . That is recognised by the provisions of s 187 of the Act (see also Trade Practices Commission v Abbco Iceworks (1994) 52 FCR 96; 123 ALR 503; BC9400002 ; Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) (2002) 217 ALR 719; [2002] NSWSC 1192; BC200208077 .
Legislation cited in [51,135.27] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128.
The provisions of s 128 do not apply to proceedings before the Coroner’s Court of NSW: Decker v State Coroner (NSW) (1999) 46 NSWLR 415; [1999] NSWSC 369; BC9901835 .

level.toc-caption: [51,135.30] Certificate of immunity — effect and procedure

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,135.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(WA) Evidence Act 1906 s 13.
(WA) Criminal Code 1913 s 422.

heading.title: Certificate of immunity — effect and procedure

p.text: The provisions of s 128 represent a significant departure from the common law by allowing, and in some instances obliging, a court to give a certificate under the present section. Such a certificate provides a witness with immunity, in relation to both the direct use of the answer, and the use of information derived from it, against them in relevant NSW proceedings — other than a “re-trial” of criminal proceedings to which s 128(9) refers: contrast R v Cornwell [2004] NSWSC 45; BC200405455 . The relevant proceedings extend to all NSW courts and adjudicative authorities irrespective of whether they are bound to apply the rules of evidence, or are merely authorised to examine evidence: see s 128(7) , compare the definition of “NSW court” and see ALRC 15.119–15.121. The system of immunity provided for in this section has precedents in some other legislation: see eg Evidence Act 1906 (WA) s 13 ; Criminal Code (WA) s 422 and Evidence Act 1910 (Tas) s 89 .

The procedure contemplated by the section depends on a witness first claiming “self incrimination” privilege. In fact, the court may be required, because of the terms of s 132 of the Evidence Act, to advise a witness about the potential availability of the privilege. Once a witness has claimed the privilege, the court must issue a certificate, in relation to any evidence to which the claim applies, if the court is, or becomes, satisfied that the claim had reasonable grounds. The court must discharge that obligation irrespective of (i) any prior ruling rejecting the privilege claim and (ii) whether the witness gave the evidence under the compulsion of a requirement under s 128(4) .
Legislation cited in [51,135.32] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128(13).
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 7A(1).
(TAS) Evidence Act 2001 s 128.
(VIC) Coroners Act 2008 s 57.
(VIC) Evidence Act 2008 s 128.
(WA) Coroners Act 1996 s 47.
(WA) Evidence Act 1906 s 11.
For the purposes of s 128(13) the provisions declared to be prescribed State or Territory provisions are set out in reg 7A(1) of the Evidence Regulation 2010:
Section 128 of the Evidence Act 2004 (Norfolk Island)
Section 128 of the Evidence Act 2001 (Tas)
Section 57 of the Coroners Act 2008 (Vic)
Section 128 of the Evidence Act 2008 (Vic)
Section 47 of the Coroners Act 1996 (WA)
Section 11 of the Evidence Act 1906 (WA)
Legislation cited in [51,135.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 Form 1, reg 7(2).

The form of certificate is provided for in Form 1 of the Evidence Regulation 2010. Compliance with that form is not a pre-condition to the efficacy of the certificate: see Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 7(2) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,140] s 128A Privilege in respect of self-incrimination — exception for certain orders etc

leg:heading.title: Privilege in respect of self-incrimination — exception for certain orders etc

p.text: In this section:

means an order made by a NSW court in a civil proceeding requiring a person to disclose information as part of, or in connection with, a freezing, search or other order under Part 25 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 but does not include an order made by a court under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 of the Commonwealth or the Confiscation of Proceeds of Crime Act 1989 or Criminal Assets Recovery Act 1990 of New South Wales.
means a person to whom a disclosure order is directed.
If a relevant person objects to complying with a disclosure order on the grounds that some or all of the information required to be disclosed may tend to prove that the person:
has committed an offence against or arising under an Australian law or a law of a foreign country, or
is liable to a civil penalty,
the person must:
disclose so much of the information required to be disclosed to which no objection is taken, and
prepare an affidavit containing so much of the information required to be disclosed to which objection is taken (the privilege affidavit) and deliver it to the court in a sealed envelope, and
file and serve on each other party a separate affidavit setting out the basis of the objection.
The sealed envelope containing the privilege affidavit must not be opened except as directed by the court.
The court must determine whether or not there are reasonable grounds for the objection.

Subject to subsection (6) , if the court finds that there are reasonable grounds for the objection, the court must not require the information contained in the privilege affidavit to be disclosed and must return it to the relevant person.
If the court is satisfied that:

any information disclosed in the privilege affidavit may tend to prove that the relevant person has committed an offence against or arising under, or is liable to a civil penalty under, an Australian law, and
the information does not tend to prove that the relevant person has committed an offence against or arising under, or is liable to a civil penalty under, a law of a foreign country, and
the interests of justice require the information to be disclosed,
the court may make an order requiring the whole or any part of the privilege affidavit containing information of the kind referred to in paragraph (a) to be filed and served on the parties.

If the whole or any part of the privilege affidavit is disclosed (including by order under subsection (6) ), the court must cause the relevant person to be given a certificate in respect of the information referred to in subsection (6)(a) .
In any proceeding in a NSW court or before any person or body authorised by a law of this State, or by consent of parties, to hear, receive and examine evidence:
evidence of information disclosed by a relevant person in respect of which a certificate has been given under this section, and
evidence of any information, document or thing obtained as a direct result or indirect consequence of the relevant person having disclosed that information,
cannot be used against the person. However, this does not apply to a criminal proceeding in respect of the falsity of the evidence concerned.
Subsection (8) does not prevent the use against the relevant person of any information disclosed by a document:
that is an annexure or exhibit to a privilege affidavit prepared by the person in response to a disclosure order, and
that was in existence before the order was made.
Subsection (8) has effect despite any challenge, review, quashing or calling into question on any ground of the decision to give, or the validity of, the certificate concerned.

If a person has been given a certificate under a prescribed State or Territory provision in respect of information of a kind referred to in subsection (6)(a) , the certificate has the same effect, in a proceeding to which this subsection applies, as if it had been given under this section.
[subs (11) insrt Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[5], effective 14 January 2011]

For the purposes of subsection (11) , a prescribed State or Territory provision is a provision of a law of a State or Territory declared by the regulations to be a prescribed State or Territory provision for the purposes of that subsection.
[subs (12) insrt Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[5], effective 14 January 2011]

Subsection (11) applies to a proceeding in relation to which this Act applies because of section 4, other than a proceeding for an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or for the recovery of a civil penalty under a law of the Commonwealth.
[subs (13) insrt Act 69 of 2010 Sch 1[5], effective 14 January 2011]
Section 87 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 makes provision with respect to protection against self-incrimination in relation to certain matters to which this section does not apply.
[s 128A insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[62], effective 1 January 2009]

level.toc-caption: [51,140.10] Certificate procedure in relation to interim preservation orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,140.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 87.

heading.title: Certificate procedure in relation to interim preservation orders

p.text: The present section, together with the related provisions in CPA s 87 provides a “certificate” procedure to facilitate the compulsory interlocutory disclosure of information that would otherwise be incriminating. The procedure complements the provisions of s 128 of the Act: see generally Specialty Fashion Group Ltd v Muirhead Nominees Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 754; BC200906832 . This certificate procedure, in its application to “freezing” and “asset preservation” orders provides a statutory resolution of difficulties that had arisen in attempts to modify the common law privilege rules, and s 128 itself, in their application to interlocutory disclosures. Those attempts had seen the adoption of a “sealed envelope” practice that required disclosure (but without either any prior ruling on any objection and without any compliance with s 128(3)–(5) . Bax Global (Australia) Pty Ltd v Evans (1999) 47 NSWLR 538; [1999] NSWSC 815; BC9904569 at [41]–[46] . But that practice was disapproved of in Ross v Internet Wines Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 436; [2004] NSWCA 195; BC200403868 as being inconsistent with Reid v Howard (1995) 184 CLR 1; 131 ALR 609; BC9506438 . And that led to a degree of controversy about an apparent lack of coherence between “the law concerning privilege against self-incrimination and the law concerning compulsory disclosure of information for the purpose of civil proceedings”); Pathways Employment Services v West (2004) 212 ALR 140; 186 FLR 330; [2004] NSWSC 903; BC200406440 at [46] per Campbell J. The section therefore introduces a regime where recipients of a disclosure order who wish to take objection to the provision of the information must include such information in an affidavit and place it in an envelope and file it with the court. The procedure includes the court being able to return the affidavit if it finds that the objection is justified.

Under the present section a person subject to a disclosure order must comply with the order, to the extent of complying with the “sealed envelope” procedure in s 128A(2) , irrespective of the merits of any incrimination privilege claim. However the contents of any affidavit provided in compliance with the disclosure order cannot be revealed unless the court rejects the privilege claim or requires disclosure in “the interests of justice”: s 128A(7) . In the latter event, the court must then issue a certificate in relation to the information disclosed.
Legislation cited in [51,140.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128A(12).
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 7A(2).
(TAS) Evidence Act 2001 Section 128A.
(VIC) Evidence Act 2008 Section 128A.
For the purposes of s 128A(12) the provisions declared to be prescribed State or Territory provisions are set out in reg 7A(2) of the Evidence Regulation 2010:
Section 128A of the Evidence Act 2001 (Tas)
Section 128A of the Evidence Act 2008 (Vic)
Legislation cited in [51,140.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 7(2).

The form of certificate is provided for in Form 1 of the Evidence Regulation 2010. Compliance with that form is not a pre-condition to the efficacy of the certificate: see Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 7(2) .
